text: Businessmen and women fill the sidewalks, clutching their winter coats shut. Most wear gloves and hats, though they provide little respite from the blustery Midwestern winds Salt-stained Taxis jockey for position. Steam billows fro manhole covers and metal grates. Metro train cars, filled capacity, howl across the frigid track.

The revolving door spins like a carousel, filled with the briefcase-carrying denizens of this busy financial center A sign, situated high above the front security desk: “STARKWEATHER FINANCIAL.” A large Christmas wreath hangs above the sign. The elevator door starts to close. A hand shoots in, stop it. The door reopens. DAVID HARGROVE, 27, more handsome than he probably realiz climbs into the crowded elevator. The other occupants bar move. The door closes -- inches from David’s face. DING. WE TRACK WITH DAVID as he: Exits onto his floor... Walks through the cubicle farm, past the other middle-inc earners and entry-level employees... Sits down in his cubicle. Tosses his car keys into a plas cup filled with pocket change, next to his small desk clo that reads 8:29AM... Pours himself a cup of coffee in the break room... Talks on his office phone, while sneaking in bites from a sandwich... The wall clock shows 1:30PM... He removes a tall stack of files from a drawer and drops on his desk... Talks on the phone some more. Stressed out... David's small, desk clock shows 4:42PM... He enters data into a computer program... Finally lets out a deep sigh. Just another day.

It’s now dark outside. Fluorescent light fills the antiseptic office. People work into the night. The wall clock reads 7:14PM. David sits at his desk, talking on the phone. Or, better described, being talked to. His tie unloosened, his hair mussed, he fails in his effo to keep stress at bay.

(into phone) Right...I understand. But, there’s so many variables that come into play in a market like this. The voice from the other end of the phone is unintelligib but its tone is unmistakably hostile.
If you'd like, we can explore shifting what's left in your 401K into...I see. COREY THOMPSON, 28, David’s somewhat overbearing and audacious friend and coworker, overhears the conversation Tunes in.
Yes. Yes, sir, I know Christmas is coming. I understand. I’m sorry, Mister Dean. Truly, I’m sorry. I spread the investment risk as wide as I could. (MORE )
It’s just the unfortunate state of the economy we’re all -- From the other end of the phone, we hear the muffled soun what sounds a lot like a string of curse words.
Hello? Hello, Mister Dean...? (sotto) Shit. David hangs up the phone. Buries his face in his hands. Rubs his temples. Corey wheels back in his chair. Leans into David’s cubicl
You lose him?
What gave it away? David powers down his computer. Corey takes a candy cane off David’s desk. Tears open the plastic wrapper. Pops it into his mouth.
Candy canes taste like shit.

I wouldn’t know. Corey smirks. David looks at himself in the reflection of his powered d computer monitor. His button-down shirt. His loosened tie His messy hair. Corey notices his dejected expression.
Hey, it’s not your fault.
(sarcastically) Oh no, who’s fault is it then? (sincere now) I’ve never even met this guy. Just moved some numbers around on the computer and now he’s fucked.
Everyone’s fucked. So stop moping. David shrugs his acknowledgment.
Maybe I should have taken today off. Corey looks across the office. Sees EMILY BRANDT, 25, attractive, chatting with a coworker.
(re: Emily) Ah, but then you would have missed your chance.
What do you mean?
Today’s her last day.
She's quitting?
That’s what I hear.
No... He watches Emily as she walks back toward her cubicle.
Stop being such a bitch and go ask her out.
I tried that a year ago. I made an ass out myself.
Yeah, because you couldn’t say the word date. What did you call it again...?
I asked her if she wanted to meet up for...a gathering.
A gathering? What is she, a fucking wizard?
No idea why I said it.
You're right, you did make an ass out yourself. David ignores Corey. Collects the last of his belongings.
Come on, come on -- I’m just messing with you. Go talk to her.
I can’t.
Why can’t you?
Because...I left my balls at home.
Not again.
Yup, right there on the dresser.
Next to your nightgown?
Right next to it. In fact, it’s probably covering them a little bit, keeping them warm.
Like a male penguin.
Like a male penguin. I don’t know what that means. David grabs his jacket and car keys.
I’1l see you on Monday.
What about the Christmas party?
Eh...
Don’t give me “eh.” We're meeting everyone at Max’s in, like, twenty minutes.
Shouldn’t I go home and change first?
You're fine; everybody's going straight from the office.
Oh...I get it now. Male penguins sit on the eggs to keep them warm...like my balls.
You got it right away. Stop trying to change the subject -- the party’s going to be fun.
Are Jerry and Luke going?
Yeah. Everybody from our department is. Besides, I need a ride.
You know all those yellow cars out there? It’s crazy, all you need to do is give them some money and they drive you wherever --
-- Yeah, yeah, yeah. Just give me a second. I gotta’ take a piss.
(through a smile) I’m not going.
Yeah you are. You wanna’ know why? David's already given up. Raises his eyebrows to say “Why
(re: Emily) Because she’s going, too. Corey walks off, leaving David to reconsider, and then y from afar.
This is going to be a big night for you, bro. I can feel it.

Busy bar scene. Young professionals enjoy after-work drin at their company Christmas party. Some enjoy too many, evidenced by Corey’s obvious inebriation. He and David sit at a table, along with coworkers CHRISTI JERRY, and LUKE. High-ball glasses cover the table. Corey iPhone also sits on the table, in front of him. Emily stands across the room, speaking with friends at th bar. Back at the table, Corey holds court.
So I purposely order the pizza at, like, three minutes before midnight.
On New Year’s Eve?
Yeah.
(to the group) What’s going on for New Year’s this year?
Who gives a shit? I’m not done with my story.
It’s going to be Easter by the time you are.
Yeah, whatever. Go fuck yourself. Anyway...where was I?
New Year’s. You ordered a pizza.
Right, right. So, three minutes passes, the ball drops, it’s officially the new year. Lo and behold, ten minutes later there’s a knock on my door.

Was it the point of the story finally showing up? David listens in. Laughs. Glances over at the bar, where sees Emily. She looks back at him. Their gaze holds for a moment, but then they both look away.
It was the pizza guy. So, I tell him, “You better not be charging me for this. I ordered the fucking thing last year!” The punchline receives a few courtesy chuckles.
Did you end up paying?

No. The kid apologized and -- As Corey plops back down into his seat, Corey accidentall bangs into the table and knocks his iPhone onto the floor He doesn’t notice. He also spills everyone's drinks. That, everyone notices.
Ah, man. What the hell?
Shit. My bad, my bad. Corey pulls out his wallet. Grabs all his cash. Calls ove a COCKTAIL WAITRESS.
(hands her all his cash) Sweetie, here. Bring a bottle of tequila to the table. Best stuff you got.
It’s five more dollars.

Oh...um... Corey searches his pockets. David stands up and places a ten dollar bill on the Cockt Waitresses’ tray. He walks away from the table. WE STAY ON DAVID as he crosses the bar. Readies himself. Approaches the bar, next to Emily. Tries to make his selection of that spot seem random. He signals the bartender.
(to the bartender) Another beer. Thanks. He turns and looks at Emily.
Oh...hey, Emily.
Hi, David. The bartender brings David his beer.
(to Emily) Did you want anything?
No, I’m good, thanks. I’m leaving, actually.
I heard that. Emily’s slightly confused.
You heard I was leaving?
Yeah. Corey told me you got a job at an NPO.
Oh, right...I did. I meant I was leaving...never mind.  10.
Well, congrats. Needed a change, I guess.
Thanks, yeah I think I’ve gone about as far as I can handle in finance.
I know what you mean. Neither of them seems to know where to go from here. The extended silence is a bit awkward.
So...I should probably get going.
Right...
Thanks for the drink -- well, the offer.
Of course. Yeah. And, ah, you know...maybe I’1l catch you later...or something.
Umm...yeah. Emily grabs her coat and purse. Walks off. David winces. Dies a little on the inside.

Cars and taxis speed past. Their exhaust mixes with the c air, clouding up the street. Emily walks from the bar and is instantly hit by an achin cold gust of wind. She extends a shivering arm to signal cab, but it passes her by. David exits the bar, carrying a winter hat. Catches up to her.
Emily, wait... Emily turns to face who called her. Sees it’s David. A hopeful smile crosses her face.  11.
You forgot your hat.
Oh...that’s not mine.
Shit. Did I just steal a hat?
I think you may have.
Well, consider it a going away present...from whoever owns it.
I’m not going far. My new office is only a few blocks uptown. David goes for broke.
Want to grab lunch some time?
Ummm.... Crash and burn. David quickly recoils.
It’s cool. I understand...
No, no -- I would. Sorry. I’m nervous.
Nervous? About what?
About this. About us talking right now.
Really?
Yes. She reaches out to another passing taxi.  12. It, too, does not stop. She grows frustrated. Cold. She moves to a spot further down the street. David walks with her.
We've talked plenty of times before. Wearing only his button-down work shirt, the cold is alre taking its toll on David. He folds his arms for warmth. Tries to rub life back into his limbs.
At work, yeah. You’d call me at my desk, ask me about a financial report, but that was it.

I never cared about the reports. They smile at each other. Their breath escapes into the c nighttime air. A cab speeds past. Emily misses the chance to signal it. Standing in the spot she stood moments ago are two women. The cab stops for them and they climb in.

(re: the missed cab) Damn it... A bone-chilling gust of wind blows through. Emily clutche her coat closer to her chest and neck. David turns away slightly, letting the brunt of the wind hit his back. Once it passes:
I can give you a ride home. Emily considers it, but then:
I live outside the city. It’s really out of the way. Another cab passes without stopping.
Come on, it’s freezing out here. I‘1l grab my jacket and we'll go. More cold wind blows through. It chills them to the bone.  13.
That would be great. Thanks. He hurries back toward the bar. Emily yells over to him.

You should probably return that hat. INT. MAX’S - MOMENTS LATER The bar is just as busy as it was when we last left it. David enters -- He places the hat on the back of a chair. Leaves it there Walks to his table. An almost full bottle of top-shelf tequila sits on it, along with several empty shot glasses
I'm taking off.
Already? David's lips form a modest smile.
I'm giving Emily a ride home. The guys at the table applaud.
See? And here it is you didn’t even want to come tonight. David smirks. Puts on his winter jacket.
I’1ll see you guys on Monday.
Alright, playboy.
Congrats. David's about to leave the table. He notices that Corey h put on his own jacket, which is half soaked from when he spilt the drinks.  14.
(patting down his jacket) Damn.
What are you doing? Corey puts his jacket over his arm instead.
What do you mean, what am I doing? We're leaving.
Well, I’m leaving...
Yeah. And you’re my ride home.
Can’t you take a cab?
I don’t have any more cash on me. Slightly frustrated, David takes out his own wallet. He doesn’t have much cash either.
I'll just go with you now.
I told you, I’m bringing Emily home.
I know. Just drop me off on the way.
Corey...
It’ll take ten minutes.
You live twenty minutes away.
What am I supposed to do -- walk?
(sighs) Okay. Let’s go.  15. Corey swipes the bottle of tequila off the table and hide under his jacket. Off the guys’ chagrined looks:
What? I’m the one who bought it. David walks away, toward the exit, with Corey following c behind.

A long stretch of darkened, suburban road, lit by the occasional street light. Small, snow-capped homes appear sporadically. The chilled limbs of wintry trees spread like spindly, bony fingers, hovering just above the road. A set of headlights cut through the darkness. INT. CAR -— CONTINUOUS David drives as Emily rides in the passenger seat, doing best to warm her hands near the dashboard vents. She stares out the window, watching the dark world outsid speed past her. Corey sits in the backseat, his bottle of tequila in hand He sips from it as he talks, unnecessarily loudly, on a c phone.

(into phone) Check my seat. Nothing? How about under the table? Yeah. Yeah, it’s an iPhone. Nice. Leave it on my desk tomorrow. Luke? Leave it...you there? Yo? Corey looks at the cell phone. It’s powered down.
(to David, re: the phone) Your battery’s dead. David plugs his car charger into the cigarette lighter.

(re: the cell phone) Let me see it.  16. David reaches his hand behind him, but Corey throws the p over David’s shoulder, onto the front seat. It lands on t floor, in a small crevice on the side of the seat.

Dude...? David reaches for the phone, but his hand doesn’t fit. He gives up. Leaves it there. They continue driving. David looks over at Emily, who kee her hands pressed against the heating vents. He slides of his jacket.
(placing the jacket over her lap like a blanket) Here.
(smiles) Thanks.
I’m sorry by the way.
For what?
I realize this is out of the way...
It's fine. Honestly. (beat) I’m enjoying the company. David and Emily share a flirtatious smirk. From the backseat, loudly:
It’s true, I am good company. Take this left. Corey tells David to take the turn just as he reaches the street. David swerves slightly, but readjusts.
Don’t worry about it. You can take the next one. David continues driving.  17. After a beat:
I’m starving. No response. Corey tries again.
You know what I’m saying?
Yeah, that you’re hungry. I get it.
Let’s grab something to eat.
It's after midnight.
And? What am I, a fuckin’ gremlin?
Yes. David smirks.
Eat at home.
I don’t have anything. C’mon, just stop somewhere.
Nothing’s open.
There’s a pizza place near here that serves slices till two. Corey's clearly too drunk to be getting the hint. David tries a more direct approach.
I kind of want to, you know, bring Emily home...
It’ll take two seconds. I swear, I'll stop this masterclass in cock- blocking right after that.  18. David looks at Emily. She laughs. David ends up doing the same.
You're killing me right now.
Cool. Oh yeah, I need to stop at an ATM.
Just use your debit card.
They only take cash...unless you wanna’ spot me --—
Where’s the ATM?

Large and dark, the lot is a vast expanse of empty area. Yellow lines demarcate the hundreds of parking spaces, th none are occupied. It’s quite barren. Eerie. Not the best part of town, either. The supermarket is closed for the night. A long, frozen, industrial hose snakes from the building to the rows of Douglas-fir trees lined near its entrance. The trees’ chilled limbs dance in the strong winds. Festooned above them, a large banner reads: “CHRISTMAS TR FOR SALE.” Nearby, beneath the supermarket’s main sign, is a large t and temperature sign. Current time: 1:18am. Temperature: negative 3 degrees Fahrenheit. Across from the supermarket, in a remote area of the park lot, sits a standalone ATM vestibule owned by BANK OF THE MIDWEST. The large, glass-encased ATM vestibule remains o for 24-hour use. David's car pulls up near the ATM vestibule. Not far, but not exactly close, either.
Emily opens her door. lLeans her seat forward. Corey squeezes through, squashing Emily in the process.  19.

I’ll be back in a second. Leaving his damp jacket in the car, Corey hurries over to entrance. The ATM vestibule shines like a beacon in the otherwise darkened parking lot. Its many windows are partially fros from the extreme cold. Corey takes a long pull from the bottle of tequila he bri with him. David and Emily watch from the car as Corey inserts his A card into the outside security reader. He pulls open the and he enters. Neither says a word at first. Silence, sav for the idling engine and the steady sound of heat escapi the vents.
I‘1ll make sure he’s fast at the pizza place...
I really don’t mind.
They actually make pretty decent pizza. The mushroom and, um, and something...garlic, I think, is pretty good. They cook it all up and stuff. It’s good. Off David’s stammering:
I thought I was the nervous one. David jokingly puffs up.
What are you talking about? I’m not nervous.
Catch you later?
Well that was -- okay, I was a little nervous then, but...
I like it. It’s cute.  20. Emily smiles. She notices a pewter clip -- featuring Sain Christopher -- attached to David’s visor.
(re: the clip) What’s that? David seems slightly embarrassed.
Oh, it’s nothing. Emily leans in and reads the inscription. Her shoulder touches David’s. Her touch electrifies him.
“Protect me and my passengers and all who pass by with a steady hand and a watchful eye.”
It’s stupid. I don’t know why I even have it.

I think it’s nice. There’s nothing wrong with having a little faith. Their conversation is interrupted by the distant sight of Corey in the ATM vestibule. It’s clear by his body langua that he’s aggravated about something.
(re: Corey) Uggg...what is it now? Corey turns to face them. Throws his hands up in resigned defeat.

You've got to be kidding me. David gets out of the car. Leaves his jacket behind on Emily's lap. Jogs over to the ATM vestibule. WE STAY ON EMILY as she watches David using his own ATM c to let himself into the vestibule. He and Corey have a br discussion, ending with David’s obvious displeasure. Emily looks around while holding her cold hands closer to heat. The emptiness and dark surroundings make her visibl uneasy.  21. After a moment, she turns off the car. Removes the keys f the ignition. Still wearing her coat, she exits the car a hurries over the ATM. WE SEE that she left behind her pur Corey opens the door and lets her into...

Large, both in length and height, the vestibule is quite roomy inside. Close to fifteen feet across. Thirteen feet high ceilings. Glass windows cover three sides of the rectangle shaped vestibule. Its fourth side is a dull, white plaster wall, cluttered with Bank of the Midwest advertisements. Off to one side of this wall is an Automated Teller Machine (ATM David stands at the ATM, going through the process of get cash. INSERT - The P.O.V. from the silent, black and white vide camera situated in the ATM: David, with Emily and Corey in the background, stands in front of the ATM. He punches in his PIN.
(to Emily) What’s wrong?
Nothing. I didn’t want to wait in the car.
I‘1l just be a second.
(to David) Why are you taking out money? David rolls his eyes over in Corey’s direction. Corey notices.
Cockhead, I’1l pay you back. (to Emily, kinder) The magnetic strip on my card’s messed up.
Cockhead?  22.
Just a little pet name I have for him. Emily chuckles. Corey, who left his coat in the car, blow into his hands for warmth.

It's freakin’ freezing in here. Emily agrees with a nod. Corey places his cold hands agai a small heating vent located along the bottom of the plas wall. It offers a small amount of relief. Transaction complete. David takes his cash. Grabs his receipt. Throws it in a waste basket.

All set, let’s go. Leading the way, Emily places her hand on the vestibule d - on the EXIT LEVER. She’s about to press the lever and o the door, when suddenly -- -- she stops. Corey and David look at her.

What? She doesn’t move. Not a muscle. Her eyes are fixed on something straight ahead in the dark parking lot. Corey and David turn their attention to what she stares a Standing there, about thirty feet from the door, is a MAN formidably sized man, at that. Shrouded in darkness, wear a heavy, hooded parka. He doesn’t move -- he simply stands and stares. WE CANNOT SEE his face, only the faint wisps of steam as curl from his mouth in the cold winter air. David, Emily and Corey stop dead in their tracks. They ne exit the vestibule.
Who the hell is that? David looks at his own hand, which is full of cash. Practically on display.  23. He quickly stuffs the cash into his pocket.
Who gives a shit? Let’s go. Corey puts his hands on the door, about to open it and ex David warily grabs Cory by the shirt.
No, wait...
For what?
Just wait. Corey stands down. The three of them stare outside at the Man. He stares back.
Why’s he out there?
He’s probably waiting to use the ATM.
Why didn’t he come in, then?
Who cares? I’m freezing. Let’s go.
Damn it, Corey. Wait. Corey stops. Let’s out an annoyed sigh.
The fucking guy wants to use the ATM. Big deal.
Where’s his card?
Probably in his wallet.
What if he wants to rob us?  24.
He’s not here to rob us.
Corey, it’s one in the morning. Why would this guy be in the middle of an empty parking lot?
(re: the ATM) The same reason we’re here.
Did we walk here? Alone? Corey looks at the Man for a beat. Considers David's assertion. After a beat:

This is retarded. I’m leaving. Corey opens the door and starts to exit. The very second does -- -- the Man takes a step closer to the ATM vestibule. Seeing this, Corey freezes. After a beat, he then slowly steps back inside the vestibule. Closes the door.
What was that? Why did he do that?
Maybe...maybe he thought we were done, so he could finally come in. They wait. Continue to look outside at the Man. He does t same right back at them.
Should we call the police?
No.
(to David) I think we should. David doesn’t respond. He holds his attention on the Man.  25.
Let’s just ask him why he’s here, then.
No...
Corey, no. Corey knocks on the glass. Calls out to the Man.
Hey, buddy. You waiting to use the
The Man does not respond. He continues to stand and stare Unflinchingly.
(unnerved) What does he want, then?
Probably our money. (beat) Does he have anything on him? Can you see?
I...I can’t tell.
Are you guys serious right now? Who cares about this jerk-off? Let's go.
Says the guy who just got scared back into the booth.
Whatever. If we all leave at once, we'll be fine. Come on. Corey puts his hands on the door, prepared to exit. David grabs onto him again.
Wait -- will you just wait?! Corey shakes David's grip off of him.  26.
For what? I want to go eat. David looks outside. The Man stares back, still standing the same spot in the parking lot.
He’s just...watching us.
The Man stands and stares at David, Emily and Corey. They stare out at him.
Emily, David and Corey keep their attention on the Man. Confused. Slightly fearful. Growing colder with each passing minute.
Maybe he’s homeless.
He probably is. So, give hima fin and let’s call it a night.
He doesn’t look homeless.
What makes someone not look homeless?
When they’re that big. Just then, the Man’s head WHIPS around. A faint jingling sound grows louder and louder. Someone’s coming.
ROBERT, 43, a random man walking his dog, ambles through parking lot, a hundred feet or so behind the Man. A medallion on his Golden Retriever’s collar jingles with e step.
(to his dog) Alright, go ahead. Robert lets go of the dog’s leash. It runs off into the dark.  27.
David, Emily and Corey watch as Robert comes into view. The Man walks over to Robert with a determined step.

Robert stands and waits for his dog to return. Bounces on the balls of his feet to keep warm. He then notices David, Emily and Corey in the ATM vestibu They all stand at the door, watching intently. He appears find this somewhat odd. Robert then sees the Man approaching.
How’s it going? The Man continues toward him. Doesn't say a word.
Just letting my dog do his business. The Man continues his approach, undeterred. Robert sudden appears to feel slightly threatened.
Is there...uh, something I can help you -- SMASH! Without a moment of hesitation, the Man PUNCHES Robert in the face. Drops him.
Oh my God! David bangs against the glass, trying to stop the Man.
Hey! Hey!!
The Man GRABS Robert’s head in his big, meaty hands, wrap in dark leather gloves and -- -- SMASH-SMASH!! Against the concrete. Like an animal. Blood trickles out from Robert’s head.  28.
Holy shit. Did you see that? Did you see that?!
David...

The Man removes Robert's wallet from his back pocket. Doesn't open it. Stuffs it into his own jacket pocket. He leaves Robert’s bloodied body in the middle of the par lot. No care. No remorse. He walks back toward the vestibule. Well behind him, Robert’s Golden Retriever returns. Nudge him a few times with his snout. Whimpers. Robert doesn’t move. The dog walks away, its leash dragging behind on th ground.

They watch in horror as the Man returns to where he was originally standing. He plants himself there. As if nothi happened. David frantically reaches into his pocket. Searches. Nothing. Reaches into his other pocket. Same result.
Damn it! (to Emily and Corey) Call nine-one-one. Call them! Corey throws his hands up. He doesn’t have his phone, remember? David looks to Emily. She sheepishly answers.
My phone’s in my purse.
Where’s your purse? Emily looks outside.
In the car.  29. Corey starts frantically looking around next to the ATM.
(running his fingers along the underside of the ATM) Don’t they have panic buttons in these things?
Yeah they must. They all join in looking for the button, but can’t find i
Shit, what about a hard line?
What do you mean?
I don’t know, like an elevator phone. A speaker thing that connects directly to the bank.
Right, right. They all continue looking around, but still they find nothing.
This can’t be happening. But it is. The three of them stare at each other, all pleading for an idea. They’ve got nothing. The gravity of the situation fully takes hold.

Chilling winds scream through the empty lot, knocking one the Christmas trees over. A small chain, fastened to its trunk, keeps it from blowing away. A few pieces of trash roll about like suburban tumbleweed The time and temperature sign provides its update. Curren time: 1:52am. Temperature: negative 5 degrees Fahrenheit. The ATM vestibule sits in the distance, aglow in the dark winter night.  30.

David paces back and forth, futilely hugging his arms clo to his body for warmth. Corey kneels near the wall, his hands near the heating ve He takes a warming sip from the bottle of tequila. Emily clenches her jacket closed as she stares into the parking lot. Her teeth chatter behind her dry, pallid lip She can’t take her frightened eyes off the Man, who slowl circles the vestibule like a shark. A predator.
There has to be something. Something we can do to, I don’t know, get someone’s attention.
Who? There’s no one else out there.
There was that guy with his dog.
And look what happened to him. David takes this into account.
(re: the Man) Why hasn’t he come in here? Corey and David look outside at the Man. Study him as the talk to each other.
Maybe he doesn’t have an ATM card.
Why would that stop him?
You need it for the buzzer thing.
What if the dog guy has one?
Has he checked?  31.
How the fuck should I know? Their concern escalates.
What are we going to do? David looks over at the car. It’s parked a good distance away.
Where are my keys? Emily digs into her jacket pocket. Removes David’s keys, well as a tube of lipstick. She hands David his keys.
Maybe I can get to the car.
You’1l never make it.
You don’t know that.
David, the guy’s right there. You'll be lucky to get within ten feet of it.
The Man notices that all three of them look in the direct of the car. It’s obvious what they’re considering. He walks toward the car.
What’s he doing?
Shit -- I think he heard us.

The Man opens the driver’s side door. Leans in. Fiddles around near the steering wheel, though WE CANNOT SEE what he’s doing. He then pushes a button to pop the trunk. Closes the driver’s side door.  32. After standing in front of it for a moment -- with his ba facing the vestibule -- he then retreats to the back of t car. Opens the trunk. A faint light emits from a small bulb. T Man carelessly rummages through the junk inside, throwing much of it to the ground, including an old, folding lawn chair. He finds a tire iron, apparently what he was looking for. Grabs it. He then spots a small tool kit. Takes that, too

They watch as the Man closes the trunk, carrying the tire iron and tool kit. He walks away from the car, toward the vestibule. Continu walking, until he’s out of sight, presumably behind the vestibule.
Is he leaving? David places his face against where the last pane of glas meets the plaster wall, trying to see the Man.
No...I can’t tell. I think he went around back. Shit. David peels away from the window.
